'''''Glamhoth''''' is a [[Sindarin]] word for [[Orcs]]. Literally, it means "the dinhorde, the yelling horde", and is a descriptive term referring to the loud and barbarous speech of the Orcs.<ref name=UT>{{UT|Tuor}}, p. 39</ref>

==Etymology==
The first part, ''glam'', means "barbaric speech", and is an expansion of ''[[lam]]'' ("tongue, language"). An individual within the group is referred to as a ''glamog''<ref>{{WJ|AC}}, p. 391</ref>. The second element, ''[[hoth]]'' is a common suffix to denote a collection of people, usually used negatively.<ref>{{S|Appendix}}</ref>

==Examples==
*''[[Gurth an Glamhoth!|Gurth an '''Glamhoth'''!]]'' = "Death to the Orcs!"
*''[[Glamdring|'''Glam'''dring]]'' = "Foe-hammer"

==Other versions of the legendarium==
This word has a long history in Tolkien's mind, but always had evil connotations. In its earliest appearances, it meant "fierce hate",<ref>{{PE|15}}, "Namelist to ''The Fall of Gondolin''", page 25</ref> but later, its meaning became "shouting, confused noise", and became (poetically) associated with [[Orcs]].

==Inspiration==
Throughout history, populations have always considered the languages of other peoples inferior, or uncouth to the ears. The term [[Wikipedia:Barbarian|"Barbarian"]] originally meant "brabbler". Similarly, Germany is called [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Names_for_Germany "Land of the Mute"], "land of those who do not speak our tongue" in some Slavic countries. A similar pattern is found in [[Adûnaic]], where the word for "shout" (''rûkh'') is related to the words for "Orc", ''[[uruk]]''.
